lines.text: THE COunCIL FOR TOBAcCO ReseaRcH-U.S.A., Inc.
October 30, 1981
MEMORANDUM
TO:
Dr. S. C. Sommers
FROM:
D. H. Ford
SUBJECT: Site visit with Dr. Ferid Murad and staff at the Palo Alto Veteran's
Administration Hospital associated with Stanford University, October
Grant No. 1186A
"Mechanism of Nitric Oxide Activation of Guanylate Cyclase"
MOVE FROM CHARLOTTESVILLE TO STANFORD:
The transition from Virginia to California appears to have been achieved
with a minimal disruption of Dr. Murad's investigations. Half of his staff moved
with him to the VA Hospital to establish the new laboratories while the other half
maintained the ongoing work at the University of Virginia and then moved out to
California early in the Fall,bringing most of their equipment. The present quar-
ters for Dr. Murad's laboratory are much larger than were available to him before.
In addition, he has eighteen fully funded lines at the VA Hospital plus six funded
on grants. He appears quite excited about the research potential at his new loca-
tion and is particularly gratified with the lines of comunication they have already
been able to establish with individuals at Stanford. Further, the general attitude
of the staff toward research appears much better. Support for equipment by the VA
is also much better than at Virginia. Thus, at this time, Dr. Murad feels that his
change in location has enhanced the program which he directs and that the administra-
tive demands he now has are no greater than they were before.
PERSONNEL:
Most of Dr. Murad's key people came with him to California. He has also
obtained a number of new Post Doctoral Fellows, most of whom havemanaged to obtain
their own financial support from private or governmental sources.
CURRENT GROUP:
John Lewicki, Ph.D.
Started 1979, plans to stay two more years.
Marty Draznin, M.D.
Started 1979, also plans to stay on a few years.
Robert Rapaport, Ph.D.
Started 1980, has a year to go.
Started 1979, also plans to stay on a few more
Scott Waldman, Ph.D.
years.
NEW:
William Pierce, Ph.D.
Started 1981
Martin Sinacore, Ph.D.
Started 1981
Germain Guryson, Ph.D.
Started 198l, trained in neuropharmacology with
Costa.
Mary Oldwurtel, Ph.D.
Coming in February, 1982
Margie Oriano, Ph.D.
Collaborating from Vermont. Works in electron
microscopy. She will be coming to Palo Alto
to work for six months on EM immunocytochemi-
cal localization of guanylate cyclase.
Larry Simons, Ph.D.
Member of Stanford faculty who has shown an in-
terest in the Murad program and may be joining

MOVE FROM CHARLOTTESVILLE TO STANFORD:
The transition from Virginia to California appears to have been achieved
with a minimal disruption of Dr. Murad's investigations. Half of his staff moved

maintained the ongoing work at the University of Virginia and then moved out to
